Award.AwardTitle: Complex Adaptive Systems as a Model for Network Evaluations (CASNET)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Complexity theory as a theoretical framework for the evaluation of the Nanoscale Information Science Education Network (NISE Net) is the focus of this evaluation research project. The researchers include evaluation scholars at the University of Minnesota and research directors at the Science Museum of Minnesota, The Museum of Science in Boston, and the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry. The intent of the project is to study how complexity theory supports evaluation capacity building within the network of informal science organizations that makes up a national community of researchers and informal science educators whose goal is to improve public awareness of, engagement in and understanding of nanoscale science, engineering and technology. Components of complexity theory that are being studied include internal diversity and redundancy, the interactions among different individuals and organizations with the network, the extent to which the control of the network is distributed, the extent of a shared goal or identity operates throughout the system established by the network, and how the system responds to change in the external environment.

This study employs a tiered case study of the way that primary actors within NISE Net are designing and implementing a new evaluation system to examine the programs that the institutions within the network are conducting. The first tier includes those individuals who are responsible for designing and implementing the resources used in the network to improve the public understanding of nanoscale science. The second tier are the individuals who use the resources developed by the network. The study utilizes a multiple case study methodology that examines individual cases that can be collected together to describe the operation of a complex network of individuals and organizations. NISE Net operates as a heterarchy whereby individuals are organized hierarchically within institutions and communicate horizontally across organizations. The case study methodology results in a framework of the evaluation efforts that will be studied iteratively using a design-based research approach to inform stakeholders and support changes in the framework as it evolves over the course of the study. Observations of the planning and implementation of evaluation efforts, document review and interviews with key stakeholders comprise the data collected and analyzed in this study.

Complex evaluation efforts such as those being conducted by NISE Net require more than simple evaluation frameworks that examine inputs, activities, outputs and outcomes. Networks by their very nature are a system of stakeholders whose interactions quickly become complex and difficult to study. Complexity theory offers the conceptual organization by which complex systems can be studied and their evaluation efforts characterized. This project informs scholars in the evaluation field about models of evaluation that support examining the quality of work being conducted by complex systems such as NISE Net. The publications intended by this study have the potential to inform the evaluation community about how complexity theory can be brought to bear to study network systems in education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This four-year NSF funded research project, Complex Adaptive Systems as a Model for Network Evaluations (CASNET), was designed to examine the evolution of evaluation capacity building (ECB) within a network using a complex adaptive system (CAS) lens. The intent of the CASNET project was to provide new insights on (1) the implications of complexity theory for designing evaluation systems that promote widespread and systemic use of evaluation within a network, and (2) complex system conditions that foster or impede ECB within a network.

The network used in this research was the Nanoscale Informal Science Education Network (NISE Net). NISE Net is a national community of researchers and informal science educators dedicated to fostering public awareness, engagement, and understanding of nanoscale science, engineering, and technology. Institutions are categorized into three levels of involvement: Tiers 1, 2, and 3, with Tier 1 being the most deeply involved in Network activities. Prior to this study, NISE Net had recently developed and instituted a specific process to expand the use of evaluative thinking across the Network, called Team-Based Inquiry (TBI). The TBI approach draws from a diversity of theoretical perspectives. It is centered on an iterative, reflective process that highlights four stages: Question, Investigate, Reflect, and Improve.

The CASNET project employed a multiple case study approach to explore and understand evaluation capacity building within the single overarching case, NISE Net. Two major subcase studies of groups from Tiers 1 and 2 were conducted and then combined to provide the overarching case study. Data were collected for both Tiers 1 and 2 through interviews of NISE Net members, reviews of documents, observations of meetings, and data from an annual Network partner survey. The findings for each of the sub cases were provided in individual reports. Additionally, a cross case synthesis report and a report documenting the lessons learned by the research team across the four years were developed. The project also developed two practitioner oriented reports, Building evaluation capacity in a complex world:  Practical lessons for organization and project leaders and CASNET coding framework, and is pursuing publications. Project materials are available at: http://www.informalscience.org/complex-adaptive-systems-model-network-evaluation .

The major findings of the cross case study are presented below.

• The NISE Net itself is a learning system, and its feedback loops mirror the processes promoted by TBI.

• A complex adaptive system can be supportive of the growth of evaluation capacity.

• Participants in a system have differing knowledge of evaluation and obtain evaluation knowledge from a variety of sources.

• To promote ECB, aspects of complex adaptive systems should be balanced, including the following:

o Centralized and decentralized control

o Coherence, diversity, and redundancy (in understanding of evaluation).

• The more local the issue, the more decentralized control of the evaluation process should be.

• Coherence and redundancy are important to building consensus for action, but diversity in understanding of evaluation is necessary to bring in new ideas and directions.

• Embeddedness in a large interconnected system allows for a variety of opportunities that support individualized growth, which in turn can move the entire evaluation system forward.

• A complex adaptive system needs to:

o Pay attention to who has control of resources for ECB

o Allow for information sharing and neighbor interactions.

The findings support the notion that the elements of an effective complex adaptive system are supportive of the growth of evaluation capacity. The NISE Net itself is a learning system and its feedback loops mirror the processes promoted by TBI. The participants in NISE Net were embedded in a system that was inherently similar to the elements necessary for ECB. It also appeared critical that the aspects of the system be balanced. Coherence and redundancy are important to build consensus for action, but diversity is necessary to bring in new ideas and directions. Being embedded in a large interconnected system allows for a variety of opportunities that support individualized growth which in turn moves the entire system forward. Not surprisingly, barriers to ECB include locally available time and resources and isolation.

The CASNET project clearly showed that NISE Net built evaluation capacity across the individuals and institutions in the network. The complex adaptive system lens allowed the CASNET project to better consider the nuances in how the system and ECB interacted to promote or inhibit growth in evaluation capacity. In today’s globally-oriented and interconnected world, networks have gained increased prominence. Networks are different from organizations where much of the work on ECB has been conducted, therefore, this research adds to the knowledge base about how to increase evaluation capacity. In addition, by using a complex adaptive system lens this research identifies new and unique insights about how a systems perspective can identify different aspects that promote or hinder ECB. Complexity theory proved to be a valuable lens for providing insights into ECB.
